citations.narrative:
- During the winter months the female spider monkey is kept in an enclosure inside a closed garage area. Her cage is
located directly beneath a garage door opener, and wires on the back of the opener are within reach of this primate if she
were to climb to the top inside of the cage. This poses a potential risk of injury and/or shock to the animal if she were to
manipulate these wires. Primary enclosures must protect nonhuman primates from injury. The top of the cage must be
secured or covered to prevent her reaching through the bars and contacting the door opener.

Several enclosures had exposed sharp points.
- A pen housing 5 wolves had two pallets with multiple exposed nail heads.
- A pen housing a single bobcat had wooden planks with exposed nail heads next to the shelter.
- An enclosure housing two coatimundis had exposed points and nail heads in several areas of the wooden structure.
Indoor and outdoor facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from
injury. Sharp points are a potential source of injury to the enclosed animals and should be removed or secured.

- In a storage area an upright freezer/refrigerator was dirty and grimy. Several shelves, including the bottom of the freezer,
were covered with old black and red liquid stains. This is a potential source of contamination to any food stored in this
area. Food supplies must be protected against deterioration and contamination. Cold storage units must be cleaned as
needed to ensure a safe food source for the animals.

- There were an excessive number of flies in the indoor storage and food prep area. The facility had one fly strip in the
room which was completely covered with flies and no longer effective. Flies and other insects are a potential source of
contamination to animals and food supplies. The facility must implement an effective pest control program to ensure flies
and other insects are adequately controlled.
This is a (1st) Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections by February 3rd 2026 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.80(a)(2)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
- During the winter months the female spider monkey is kept in an enclosure inside a closed garage area. Her cage is 
located directly beneath a garage door opener, and wires on the back of the opener are within reach of this primate if she 
were to climb to the top inside of the cage. This poses a potential risk of injury and/or shock to the animal if she were to 
manipulate these wires. Primary enclosures must protect nonhuman primates from injury. The top of the cage must be 
secured or covered to prevent her reaching through the bars and contacting the door opener. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Several enclosures had exposed sharp points. 
- A pen housing 5 wolves had two pallets with multiple exposed nail heads.  
- A pen housing a single bobcat had wooden planks with exposed nail heads next to the shelter. 
- An enclosure housing two coatimundis had exposed points and nail heads in several areas of the wooden structure. 
Indoor and outdoor facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from 
injury. Sharp points are a potential source of injury to the enclosed animals and should be removed or secured. 
3.125(c) 
   
Facilities, general. 
- In a storage area an upright freezer/refrigerator was dirty and grimy. Several shelves, including the bottom of the freezer, 
were covered with old black and red liquid stains. This is a potential source of contamination to any food stored in this 
area. Food supplies must be protected against deterioration and contamination. Cold storage units must be cleaned as 
needed to ensure a safe food source for the animals. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
- There were an excessive number of flies in the indoor storage and food prep area. The facility had one fly strip in the 
room which was completely covered with flies and no longer effective. Flies and other insects are a potential source of

contamination to animals and food supplies. The facility must implement an effective pest control program to ensure flies 
and other insects are adequately controlled. 
 
This is a (1st) Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections by February 3rd 2026 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
